about.header: For the past seven years I have enjoyed working on web and mobile applications. There’s never a dull moment as a software engineer. Whether it’s learning new languages, technologies, or spending countless hours finding a streamlined solution to a problem, there’s always room for improvement. I enjoy my profession because there is always something new to learn and the knowledge that you acquired can be applied across the board to different applications.

bulletPoints.text: My introduction to programming was via the FileMaker platform building custom distributed desktop applications. This then evolved into working with the Groovy programming language for building simple plug-ins. I was formally introduced to Java in the graduate program of Software Engineering at Kennesaw State University. I worked with Java at the enterprise level for Manheim. At Manheim I also worked with JavaScript (JS) in many projects. I have used JS to build frontend (Web App), backend (Node.js) and mobile (React Native) applications. In my last role at Manheim, I was part of a team that mainly worked on Ruby applications. The team also owned and actively built applications using Elixir. Currently at Infor I use Java and Spring Boot applications. I worked with Python in an academic setting. At Georgia Tech I used Python to implement AI algorithms for image processing and network programming.

I have built Restful services, micro applications, and backend-for-the-frontend applications using Spring Boot. On the frontend I worked on large web application that managed user inventory and an application that managed user preferences. AngularJS is a nice framework for the frontend. It provides everything needed to build a large frontend application. In my last Angular project, I worked mainly with FormControl and FormGroup for managing user data and validations. For backend services, I used Camel early in my career to build route-based applications that served as bridges between legacy AS400 PCML calls and microservices. I have worked on tech stack dominated by Ruby on Rails, elixir, and NodeJS lambdas that run on the AWS cloud. In my current role I work with Spring Boot and Hazelcast as the main frameworks.

Working in a fast-pace agile environment it is essential to have tools that will increase productivity but also provide flexibility. Besides using essential tools such as Git, Docker, and Jenkins, I have also used React for building web applications at the enterprise level. In my previous assignment I took over the management and enhancements to a React Native application for both Android and iOS. I used React to build this site. I was first exposed to AWS at Manheim. At Manheim developers are required to also manage their own DevOps and leverage dedicated DevOps personnel when needed. I have worked with a wide range of services provided by AWS.

I have used PostgresSQL and MySql as the datastore to microservices and micro applications. I was exposed to Kafka streaming applications while working for LivePerson. I helped build several processors, consumers, and producers using Spring Boot and Java 8. I worked for a team that managed async operations in a stream fashion. The events were generated and passed through several processors until reaching a subscribed consumer. In my current role I'm part of a team that builds services for clients to query a data lake via SQL dialects

items.info: Security and Networking: Intro To Info Security, Computer Networks and Network Security
items.text: These courses over security and networking exposed me to graduate-level material and projects around the fundamentals of security and networking. In Intro to Security, I was exposed to a broad spectrum of security concepts such as risk management, software, OS, database security, malicious malware, network threats and defenses, web security, mobile security and legal and ethical concepts. The projects for this class ranged from buffer overflow attacks, malware analysis to  implement SQL Injection, XSS, and XSRF attacks. For Network Security the projects ranged from vulnerability scanning and penetration tests to machine learning for security. For Computer Network, I was exposed to research topics in computer networking. The projects performed for this class ranged from virtualized network topology, Spanning Tree Protocol to coding the firewall implementation and writing firewall rules.

AI helped me build a foundation and understanding for classic AI problems. In this course, I was tasked with building a game playing AI using minimax algorithm with heuristics and alpha-beta pruning. I implemented several search algorithms such as PriorityQueue, Breadth First Search, Uniform Cost Search, A* Search and Bi-directional Search. I implemented Bayesian networks to calculate the probability of discrete random variables.  I built, trained and tested decision tree models to perform basic classification tasks. I learned about image segmentation with k-means clustering to segment a color image and building a Gaussian mixture model to be trained with expectation-maximization and experimented with Bayesian information criterion. The final projects consisted of decoding Morse code using Hidden Markov Models. In KBAI, I worked on building an agent that could pass Raven’s Progressive Matrices test.

items.info: Software Dev Process (Java), Graduate Intro to OS (C/C++) and Educ Tech-Foundations
items.text: These classic CS courses exposed me to a range of concepts from building native mobile applications with a team using agile methodologies to building and implemented distributed file system. I had a lot of fun implementing inter-process communication and building multithreading web servers in the operating systems class. For SDP, I built several mobile applications and completed projects on how to use Git and UML. In Educ Tech-Foundations, as my project I build an Android game for learning and playing the abucus.

This course exposed me to formal concepts for how human interact with computers. These concepts provide a wider perspective and reasoning on how the designing and evaluating of design are user-centered around finding the ask/need, prototyping and evaluation. These skills had to be applied through several projects and a final team project that enhanced and connected the concepts of these course.

This course consisted of projects around image processing concepts. I completed projects dealing with epsilon photography, camera obscura, blending, panoramas, HDR and video textures. Please see link below for final portfolio.
